intro: Thapsus linnaei, commonly known as the Linnaean thapsus, is a rare flowering plant native to specific regions in Europe. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes parsley and carrots, and is characterized by its delicate, umbellate inflorescence. The plant typically grows in moist, calcareous soils and is often found in meadows and woodland edges. Its small, white to greenish flowers bloom in late spring, attracting various pollinators. Due to habitat loss, it is considered endangered in many areas, making conservation efforts crucial for its survival.
